title: Data Science for Social Good
text:
Data are not neutral, nor are the algorithms that control how the data that governs our lives are used. Interpretations and recommendations made using data are subjective. This course introduces students how to start harnessing the power of data to intelligently cope with the requirements of citizenship, employment, and family to be prepared for a healthy, happy and productive life.
Students will practice collecting and wrangling data into a usable form, visualizing large data sets to discover patterns, representing data in a meaningful way, exploring varying interpretations of the data and results, and discussing potentials for misuse and abuse. This course promotes critical reflection on the ethical, social, cultural, and political dimensions of data as well as providing direct hands on experience with both spreadsheets, and the programming language R.
Students from all majors are welcome! No prior programming experience is expected, however basic ability to use a computer is needed. Additional help is available for students needing extra support with either/both computers or math.



   2 hrs lecture, 2 hrs lab
   MW 12 - 12:50PM HOLT 171
   Th 12 - 1:50PM LANG 300




GE B4 Ready or ALEKS PPL proctored assessment 46+ required.



TBD Week 1




   Dr. Robin Donatello
   Holt Hall 202
   rdonatello@csuchico.edu
   Schedule an appointment








Tip



You can toggle dark mode by clicking the  button in the top right navigation bar.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Dr. Robin Donatello (she/her)
You can address me as “Robin”, “Dr. D”, or some other respectful title that you feel comfortable with.
I have a Doctorate in Public Health (DrPH) Biostatistics from UCLA, but I’m a Chico alum. I double majored in Statistics & Biology, with minor in Chemistry, and a first generation college student who started at Butte College.
My campus life consists of training the next generation of Scientists how to harness the power of Statistics and Data in a responsible and ethical manner, leading the Data Science Initiative (DSI) provide training and experiences for students and faculty, and providing analytical support and statistical consulting for many projects on and off campus.
When I’m not on campus, typically I’m growing food for my family, out adventuring with my dogs, or getting some game time in. You can learn more about the projects i’m involved in on my website.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Your turn

Turn to your neighbor and introduce yourself.
You’ll post an introduction in Discord this week so everyone will get to know everyone else.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Everyone is welcome here
It is my intent that students from all diverse backgrounds and perspectives be well-served by this course, that students’ learning needs be addressed both in and out of class, and that the diversity that the students bring to this class be viewed as a resource, strength and benefit.
It is my intent to present materials and activities that are respectful of diversity: gender identity, sexuality, disability, age, socioeconomic status, ethnicity, race, nationality, religion, and culture.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Supportive Learning Environment
I would like to create a learning environment that supports a diversity of thoughts, perspectives and experiences, and honors your identities (including race, gender, class, sexuality, religion, ability, etc.)

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
To help accomplish this:

Let me know if you have a name and/or set of pronouns that differ from those that appear in your official Chico records.
Help me pronounce your name as accurately as possible. Corrections are welcome.
If you feel like your performance in the class is being impacted by your experiences outside of class, please don’t hesitate to come and talk with me. I want to be a resource for you.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Mitigating our risk of COVID-19

This is still a real thing, but we all have different levels of risk we are willing to take ourselves, and different risk management strategies.
I personally am working on reducing my mask wearing to re-challenge my immune system, but I also have immunocompromised elderly mother at home. Always a balance.
Masks will ALWAYS be welcome and respected in this classroom. No questions.
I am likely to request masks be worn in my office.
Please keep up to date with available booster shots. You can’t learn if you’re ill. 
If you have COVID symptoms, 🛑 Do not come to class. I’ll turn on Zoom for the day so you can participate.
If you are just generally feeling unwell, please use a mask. I will always have some on hand.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Course Description
The theory and application of survey sampling techniques. Topics include simple random sampling, stratified sampling, systematic sampling, and cluster sampling. Appropriate for mathematics, computer science, psychology, social science, agriculture, biology, and other majors.
By “survey” we do not strictly mean a self report survey such as the Student Feedback on Teaching. The concept is much broader.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Motivating Example
Go to Canvas, week 0 module and read through the motivating example. Then respond to this thread by writing a few sentence summary of the example and include your take away message.
Read through all posts later this week to see how similar, or different their messages are from yours. We all come to this class from different backgrounds and perspectives, and so will see things differently. You are welcome and encouraged to respond to other’s posts.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Learning goals

Define principal concepts, advantages and disadvantages of sampling.
Categorize, define, compare between, and implement various sampling methods such as Simple Random Sampling, Stratified Sampling, and Cluster Sampling.
Formulate and calculate appropriate estimators and confidence intervals for population parameters under various sampling frameworks.
Estimate the convenient or optimal sample size for various sampling methods.
Design, conduct, and analyze your own data collection mini-study
Bonus: You’ll get really good at writing R functions.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
section: A variety of learning and working tools
text:
A variety of learning and working tools

Many of you have had me as an instructor in the past, so some of this won’t be new.
I use a combination of tools that are most appropriate for the task or outcome at hand.
Homework 0 provides a checklist for getting connected and testing out your tools.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Class website

https://sampling-458.netlify.app/

Bookmark this page. You will be here a lot. Going through Canvas each time is a waste of your time and clicks.
Contains a weekly overview, lecture notes, homework files, relevant links.
Sometimes links will be broken. Typo’s happen. Notify me via Discord and I’ll get to it asap.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Textbook

Sampling, 3rd Edition. Sharon Lohr
Download the R companion for the book from this site as well. I anticipate it’ll be useful.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Canvas

Canvas is new to me, and it seems reasonable for organizing due dates & submissions so we’ll try that out
It’ll be your gradebook as well.
Content is organized into Modules, with flow and due dates
I will also put links to files that you need to download here.


I reserve the right to adjust where links and content are contained throughout the semseter if I find Canvas not to be the right tool at this time for me (or perhaps it will work better?)

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Discord

Used for outside class discussions, meme sharing, homework help and general chatter.
I will not answer most class-content based questions through email.
Download either the phone app or the desktop app (I use both). This is mandatory.

Do not rely on remembering to log in via the web browser. You will miss important notifications.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Learning Content

HTML based notes that to start out with are semi-complete. Example
During class we will work together through examples, you will work together on “you try it” practice problems, and answer questions
You will have a version of these notes that have blank spots for you to fill in, or answer questions

You will compile these notes to PDF and submit them through Canvas a few days after we complete a section

I will update the online posted notes with our collaborative solutions to the “you try it” problems.
As the term progresses, you will be creating sections of these notes (that will be posted) and “teaching” the rest of the class your topic.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Hack MD

Account setup instructions part of HW0
Interactive markdown based collaborative notes
I will give you a file for the first set of ‘blank’ notes.
Afterward you will be responsible for copying them (and sometimes filling out sections) of the notes directly in HackMD.

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
R + R Studio

We will be using the R programming language, along with Rstudio the Integrated Development Environment. More info on how to download and update your system can be found in Hw0.
New to R? I recommend you also enroll in Math 130 ASAP. This semester it is asynchronous online. This is a 5 week primer to get you from zero to basic ability to import, visualize and manage data.

Just need a refresher/jump start? Everything is online https://norcalbiostat.github.io/MATH130/

title: Welcome to MATH 185
text:
Graded Content

Worksheets, homework assignments, notes, exams, and a project.
Details in the Syllabus.

title: Lab 01: Intro Computing for Data Science
text:
This lab serves to level the playing field when it comes to basic computer literacy. For everyone to succeed, everyone must be presented the same information. Not all students coming into this class have had the opportunity to work with computers often, and even if you have, you may not be uses to using computers in the way that we will be doing so in this class.
Computers are not like phones, where apps 1-click install to a location you don’t need to care about, and “just work”. To set yourself up for success in school, research and professional life it is well worth your time to take a moment and look at how to use a computer in a professional setting.


This is a follow-along lab. The activities and questions that are asked are designed to have you learn or practice something, without the lecture part. This lets you more actively participate in your learning. Some parts you are asked to do on your own, such as reading a short article, or watching & listening to a short external video. Other times you will be following along as the instructor demonstrates how to accomplish a task.
Often you will be asked to Google something. This is not a cop-out on my part as a way to not write instructions, learning how to effectively search for information on the internet is one of the course objectives. So we’ll practice this activity often.






👉 Do this



Grey/Blue boxes like this are instructions for you to do something.








✏️ Check your knowledge



Green boxes like this indicates that this is a question for you to answer. Pay attention to where you should be answering these questions at. E.g. Canvas, Rstudio or somewhere else. This will be specified in the submission instructions section.





Write your answers and submit your screenshots to the lab assignment “quiz” in Canvas.

title: Lab 01: Intro Computing for Data Science
text:
File names






👉 Do this



Review Jenny’s slide deck.


Content in this section is credited to Naming things by Jenny Bryan.
TLDR;
🛑 myabstract.docx
🛑 Joe’s Filenames Use Spaces and Punctuation.xlsx
🛑 figure 1.png
🛑 fig 2.png
🛑 JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*.txt ✅ 2014-06-08_abstract-for-sla.docx
✅joes-filenames-are-getting-better.xlsx
✅fig01_scatterplot-talk-length-vs-interest.png
✅fig02_histogram-talk-attendance.png
✅1986-01-28_raw-data-from-challenger-o-rings.txt
Three principles for file names

Machine readable

avoid spaces, punctuation, accented characters, case sensitivity

Human readable

name contains information on content

Plays well with default ordering

put something numeric first, use proper dates, left pad numbers with zero


Text
You may be used to using Sentence case such as

Math 185 homework 1.docx
Donatello CV as of Feb 2021.pdf

These are human readable because we can figure out what the file is about based on the name. But they still violates principle #1 & 3.
Revised names:

hw01_math185_rdonatello.docx
2021-02_CV

Left pad numbers with zeros
This means to use 01 instead of 1.
if you don’t left pad, you get this:
10_final-figs-for-publication.R
1_data-cleaning.R
2_fit-model.R
which is just sad
Use YYYY-MM-DD for standard dates

title: Lab 01: Intro Computing for Data Science
text:
File locations
For the love of all that is holy, DON’T SAVE FILES IN YOUR DOWNLOADS FOLDER!
I had to get that out of my system.
A file path is like directions for your computer on how to find your file.






👉 Do this



Look at the examples of file paths on different systems in the linked Wikipedia article.



A back slash \ indicates a sub-folder.
Not all places that are easy to access using a mouse have a short path

C:\Users\rdonatello\Desktop\New folder

Long paths don’t always indicate lack of organization

C:\Users\rdonatello\Box\CHC All\01. Projects Active\SNAP-Ed on Campuses (SP6485201, 02)\08. Research and Evaluation\02. Data Analysis\shared reports








👉 Do this



Start to create good habits for yourself by saving files in an organized manner.

Decide on a location for files associate with this class. This CANNOT be your downloads folder.
Create a class folder, and a homework subfolder
Download this file and save it in your homework subfolder. Give it a file name that meets the three principles listed above.









✏️ Check your knowledge




Submit a screenshot of your class folder with downloaded file.

Write out the full path, including file name to the downloaded file.




How to find a path to a file in Windows 10
How to find a path to a file on Mac

title: MATH 185 Syllabus
text:
Data are not neutral, nor are the algorithms that control how the data that governs our lives are used. Interpretations and recommendations made using data are subjective. This course introduces students how to start harnessing the power of data to intelligently cope with the requirements of citizenship, employment, and family to be prepared for a healthy, happy and productive life.
Students will practice collecting and wrangling data into a usable form, visualizing large data sets to discover patterns, representing data in a meaningful way, exploring varying interpretations of the data and results, and discussing potentials for misuse and abuse. This course promotes critical reflection on the ethical, social, cultural, and political dimensions of data as well as providing direct hands on experience with both spreadsheets, and the programming language R.
Students from all majors are welcome! No prior programming experience is expected, however basic ability to use a computer is needed. Additional help is available for students needing extra support with either/both computers or math.



Name & pronouns: Dr. Robin Donatello (Dr. D, she/her)
Website: https://www.norcalbiostat.com/
Office Location: Holt 202
E-mail: rdonatello@csuchico.edu
Best Contact Method: Discord
Student Office Hours: Times TBD





Mode of Instruction: In person
Meeting Pattern: MW: 12-12:50am HOLT 171, Thu 12-1:50 LANG 300
Prerequisites: GE B4 Ready or ALEKS PPL proctored assessment 46+ required.





Class Website:
Laptop & Internet: Expect to bring your laptop to class every day.
Data Analysis software: All software is free to download and use.

Microsoft Excel
R (the programming language), and R Studio (the environment), via Posit Cloud

Textbooks: All reading materials are free and available online.

Computational and Inferential Thinking: The foundations of Data Science. Data8
R for Data Science R4DS 2nd Edition
Bit by Bit: Social Research in the Digital Age, 1st edition BBB

Canvas: Module overview, assignments, gradebook, calendar.
Discord: A free discussion platform with a lot of collaborative functionality.

Instructions for signing up & obtaining materials are in HW 0. Contact me ASAP if any of this (reliable laptop, internet or cost of Rstudio) poses a problem or concern for you. I can’t assist if you don’t communicate your needs with me.

title: MATH 185 Syllabus
text:
Everyone is welcome here
It is my intent that students from all diverse backgrounds and perspectives be well-served by this course, that students’ learning needs be addressed both in and out of class, and that the diversity that the students bring to this class be viewed as a resource, strength and benefit. It is my intent to present materials and activities that are respectful of diversity: gender identity, sexuality, disability, age, socioeconomic status, ethnicity, race, nationality, religion, and culture. Your suggestions are encouraged and appreciated. Please let me know ways to improve the effectiveness of the course for you personally, or for other students or student groups.
I would like to create a learning environment that supports a diversity of thoughts, perspectives and experiences, and honors your identities (including race, gender, class, sexuality, religion, ability, etc.) To help accomplish this:

Let me know if you have a name and/or set of pronouns that differ from those that appear in your official Chico records. I make it a point to call on people by name, so please make sure that I know what you want to be called. - I also want to try to pronounce your name as accurately as possible. The more you help and correct me the better I can do to honor your name.
If you feel like your performance in the class is being impacted by your experiences outside of class, please don’t hesitate to come and talk with me. I want to be a resource for you. Remember that you can also submit anonymous feedback using the feedback button on the schedule and help pages of the website (which will lead to me making a general announcement to the class, if necessary to address your concerns).
If you prefer to speak with someone outside of the course, the Office of Diversity and Inclusion is here to assist. Their number is 530-898-4764, and email diversityoffice@csuchico.edu
I (like many people) am still in the process of learning about diverse perspectives and identities. If something was said in class (by anyone) that made you feel uncomfortable, please talk to me about it. (Again, anonymous feedback is always an option).

Adapted from Monica Linden at Brown University.
Furthermore, I would like to acknowledge that Chico State stands on lands that were originally occupied by the first people of this area, the Mechoopda. I recognize their distinctive spiritual relationship with this land and the waters that run through campus. I am humbled that our campus resides upon sacred lands that once sustained the Mechoopda people for centuries.

title: MATH 185 Syllabus
text:
Attendance
All students are expected to attend class in person each session. There is no specific plan for habitual synchronous hybrid zoom session, but I recognize things come up.
Talk to me ahead of time if you need to miss a class for a planned reason. In the event of an unplanned reason, DM me in Discord and let’s see if we can zoom you in for that day.

If you are not feeling well or are experiencing COVID symptoms DO NOT COME TO CLASS. DM me in Discord we’ll make a backup plan.

title: MATH 185 Syllabus
text:
Collaboration
Collaboration on homework and labs is encouraged. People learn better when they have someone else to talk through concepts with. Collaboration on individual quizzes is not allowed.

Use of ChatGPT in this course

title: MATH 185 Syllabus
text:
Chico State Basic Needs Project
The Hungry Wildcat Food Pantry provides supplemental food, fresh produce, CalFresh application assistance and basic needs referral services for students experiencing food and housing insecurity.
All students are welcomed to visit the Pantry located in the Student Service Center 196, open Monday-Friday
Please visit the Chico State Basic Needs website http://www.csuchico.edu/basic-needs for more information.

title: MATH 185 Syllabus
text:
Wildcat Computing Support
Everyone’s journey through education is different and varied. Part of your journey is learning to engage and leverage academic technology. It is extremely important to your success, and at the same time requires patience to learn how it can benefit you. While learning various technologies, they change and adapt quickly. Wildcat Computing Support is curated by students to better support you and enhance your experiences with technology. We provide information to support your success in using academic technology in and out of the classroom.
https://www.csuchico.edu/wcs/

title: MATH 185 Syllabus
text:
Americans with Disabilities Act
If you need course adaptations or accommodations because of a disability or chronic illness, or if you need to make special arrangements in case the building must be evacuated, please make an appointment with me as soon as possible, or see me during office hours. Please also contact Accessibility Resource Center (ARC) as they are the designated department responsible for approving and coordinating reasonable accommodations and services for students with disabilities. ARC will help you understand your rights and responsibilities under the Americans with Disabilities Act and provide you further assistance with requesting and arranging accommodations. We try our best to ensure equal access to materials in accessible formats. Reach out to your me if there is some aspect of the course materials that are inaccessible to you.
Accessibility Resource Center 530-898-5959 Student Services Center 170 arcdept@csuchico.edu http://www.csuchico.edu/arc

title: MATH 185 Syllabus
text:
Adding and Dropping the course
You are responsible for understanding the policies and procedures about add/drops, academic renewal, etc., found in the CSU Chico University Catalog. You should be aware of the new deadlines and penalties for adding and dropping classes.

title: MATH 185 Syllabus
text:
Confidentiality and Mandatory Reoprting
As an instructor, one of my responsibilities is to help create a safe learning environment on our campus. I also have a mandatory reporting responsibility related to my role as a your instructor. I am required to share information regarding sexual misconduct with the University. Students may speak to someone confidentially by contacting the Counseling and Wellness Center (898-6345) or Safe Place (898-3030). Information on campus reporting obligations and other Title IX related resources are available here: www.csuchico.edu/title-ix.

title: MATH 185 Syllabus
text:
Academic Integrity
Academic integrity is defined as “a commitment, even in the face of adversity, to five fundamental values: honesty, trust, fairness, respect, and responsibility”. From these values flow principles of behavior that enable academic communities to translate ideals to action. Academic integrity is expected and required. No forms of cheating or plagiarism will be tolerated. Please see your student handbook at https://www.csuchico.edu/scrr/integrity.shtml if you have questions about the meaning of these terms or the consequences of violating academic integrity.
